question: What does Medicare Part A cover?
answer_snippet: Inpatient care in hospitals, Skilled nursing facility care, Hospice care, Home health care

question: What services are included in Medicare Part B?
answer_snippet: Services from doctors and other health care providers, Outpatient care, Home health care, Durable medical equipment, Many preventive services

question: What is Medicare Part D?
answer_snippet: Helps cover the cost of prescription drugs (including many recommended shots or vaccines)

question: What are the two main ways to get Medicare coverage?
answer_snippet: Original Medicare and Medicare Advantage (also known as Part C)

question: What does Original Medicare include?
answer_snippet: Medicare Part A (Hospital Insurance) and Part B (Medical Insurance)

question: Can you add prescription coverage to Original Medicare?
answer_snippet: You can join a separate Medicare drug plan to get Medicare drug coverage (Part D)

question: What is Medicare Advantage?
answer_snippet: A Medicare-approved plan from a private company that offers an alternative to Original Medicare, usually bundling Part A, Part B, and Part D

question: Can you use any doctor with Medicare Advantage?
answer_snippet: In many cases, you can only use doctors and other providers who are in the plan’s network

question: Does Original Medicare require referrals to see a specialist?
answer_snippet: In most cases, you don’t need a referral to use a specialist

question: Is there an out-of-pocket maximum with Original Medicare?
answer_snippet: There’s no yearly limit on what you pay out of pocket, unless you have supplemental coverage

question: What is the Initial Enrollment Period for Medicare Part A and Part B?
answer_snippet: The 7-month period that begins 3 months before the month you turn 65 and ends 3 months after, with adjustments if your birthday is on the first of the month.

question: When does Medicare coverage start if I sign up during my Initial Enrollment Period?
answer_snippet: If you sign up in the first 3 months, coverage starts the first day of your birthday month; if your birthday is on the 1st, it starts the previous month.

question: What is a Special Enrollment Period for Medicare?
answer_snippet: It allows you to sign up after your Initial Enrollment Period if you had group health coverage based on current employment.

question: When does coverage start if I enroll during a Special Enrollment Period?
answer_snippet: Coverage generally starts the first day of the month after you sign up.

question: Does COBRA count for a Special Enrollment Period?
answer_snippet: No, COBRA isn’t considered coverage based on current employment and doesn’t qualify you for a Special Enrollment Period.

question: What are some exceptional situations that allow Special Enrollment?
answer_snippet: Natural disasters, incarceration, health plan errors, loss of Medicaid, and other Medicare-approved circumstances.

question: What is the General Enrollment Period for Medicare?
answer_snippet: January 1–March 31 each year for those who missed Initial and don’t qualify for Special Enrollment; coverage starts the month after sign-up.

question: Should I get Medicare Part B if I have employer or union health coverage?
answer_snippet: You may delay Part B if you have coverage through current employment without penalty; verify with your benefits administrator.

question: What types of coverage do not count as current employment-based coverage?
answer_snippet: COBRA, retiree plans, VA coverage, individual marketplace plans, and coverage from severance or layoffs.

question: Do I need to sign up for Part A and B if I have TRICARE or CHAMPVA?
answer_snippet: Yes, unless you're active-duty or a family member of one; CHAMPVA always requires both Part A and B.

question: Can Medicaid help with Medicare Part A and B costs?
answer_snippet: Yes, through a Medicare Savings Program, your state may help pay premiums if you qualify.

question: How can I avoid paying a Medicare Part D late enrollment penalty?
answer_snippet: Enroll when first eligible, maintain creditable drug coverage, and keep proof of it.

question: What is the Medicare Part D late enrollment penalty formula?
answer_snippet: The penalty is 1% of the national base beneficiary premium ($36.78 in 2025) times the number of uncovered months.

question: What happens if I disagree with a Medicare drug coverage penalty?
answer_snippet: You can request a review by submitting a reconsideration form within 60 days of the notice.

question: Does Medicare Part D cover insulin?
answer_snippet: Yes, and plans can’t charge more than $35 for a one-month supply of each covered insulin product.

question: Can I automatically get prescription refills by mail under Medicare?
answer_snippet: Some plans offer voluntary auto-ship programs for prescription drugs.

question: What is Medication Therapy Management under Part D?
answer_snippet: It’s a free service for qualifying members to help manage and understand their medications safely.

question: What are common Medicare drug plan coverage rules?
answer_snippet: They include prior authorization, quantity limits, step therapy, and opioid safety checks.

question: How does Medicare handle opioid safety?
answer_snippet: Plans check prescriptions for safety risks and may require limited supply, especially if multiple providers are involved.

question: What should I know about creditable drug coverage and employer plans?
answer_snippet: Keep annual notices from your employer or union about whether their drug coverage is creditable to avoid penalties.

question: Does COBRA count as creditable drug coverage?
answer_snippet: It may count, but Medicare may still pay first. You get a Special Enrollment Period when COBRA ends.

question: Can I keep drug coverage through an old Medigap policy?
answer_snippet: Yes, but most are not creditable, and you may pay more if you join Part D later.

question: Is the Federal Employee Health Benefits Program considered creditable coverage?
answer_snippet: Yes, FEHB coverage usually includes creditable drug coverage, so enrolling in Medicare Part D isn’t required.

question: What is the Postal Service Health Benefits Program?
answer_snippet: A new program for Postal Service employees and retirees that replaces FEHB and includes creditable drug coverage.
